title: From Language Learning Platform to Infrastructure for Research on Language Learning
segmentation: Hi, I'm.
Save it and I'm a PhD student.
That's pro punk and the National Language Bank of Sweden at the University of Gothenburg, and this is a collaboration with my supervisors.
Illinova Latina, Los Pauline.
My former office colleague artistic appeal on Antares Lindstrom see demand from the University of Finland.
And this is the presentation overview, so I will talk a lot about left com, which stands for if translated, learn language through corpus analysis and incidentally also stands for lock the bird.
I will give you a short overview over what letter is and how it came into being.
Then I will talk about language, lacquer for learning and teaching.
Then go over to Alaska as a research infrastructure and then conclude by ongoing work, future work and conclusion.
So lack A is an intelligence computer, assisted language learning platform developed at the club in be centers Pro Punkin and it's freely available at this address.
And it started actually as a system architecture for Icon which had the aim to re implement some of the ITG functionality which is a system for teaching grammar using modern language technology.
And from that has finally the bird latiker.
As I said, it's openly available.
It's web based.
And it builds on a variety of existing suite login resources such as core for querying corpora, card for querying lexical resources.
And a lot of other language technology tools.
It has a service oriented architecture which means that while we provide graphical user interfaces for all of the functionalities in Latika.
We also provide an API so that you can use the functionalities within your own programs.
So for learning and teaching.
We have two target loaner groups.
The first one is students of Swedish linguistics and the second one is learners or second and following languages.
In this case it's Swedish.
And the main functionality of Alaska is that it automatically generates exercises based on real life authentic language examples from corpora.
So the first target group is linguists, and for the exercise part we have three different exercises.
World class syntactic relations and semantic quotes.
And you get immediate automatic feedback and you also have the option to send a log of your results to teacher and to yourself or to whoever you want to.
What class and syntactic relations we have two levels of difficulty, beginner and intermediate, and for semantic roles only one level.
We also have three modes.

One is self study where you can just study on your own and correct your responses to see whether if it was incorrect you can change it still in test mode you cannot change your response and in diagnostic test you get.
Three items of each category.
And in the end you will get a detailed evaluation.
So if that was a bit abstract, let me show you what it looks like.
This is let go if you go to the linquist exercise generation and at the moment as you can see, you can see nothing.

But there are these part of speech where it says simple and then 11 or 11 word classes selected and below that you see substudy diagnostic test and test modes and if you click on the menu you can see that you can select different exercises.
So part of speech, syntactic relations, semantic roles and in the menu on the right side you can actually customize it.
So for part of speech for example you can select which word classes you want to train on.
And this menu changes of course, in accordance to what you have chosen for exercise type.
Then when you do generate the exercises, you get each time a sentence and then some words marked in orange.
And using multiple choice dropdown menu you select the answer which you think is correct and as you can see on this picture you get the feedback in the form of a cross.
If it's an incorrect the answer tick mark if it's correct.

This has been used in introductions to grammar and linguistics in Sweden and Finland in lab sessions where the teacher was present and people were also encouraged to discuss the results with their fellow students.
Which is interesting because of course, this is all automatically generated, and it's not always correct.
So sometimes the system says your answer is incorrect, even if it's correct, and then it can be very interesting to discuss with fellow students why they think the system thinks this is incorrect.
In general, students perceived it as a good tool and they would also like to use it in the future.

Now going over to the second target group of learners language learners, we have at the moment for different exercise types, namely for capillary, multiple choice, inflection, multiple choice word guess which is based on the hangman principle and Alyssa Netwide exercise.
So this is what the multiple choice exercise looks like.
As you can expect, you have a sentence and then a gap in it, and then using a dropdown multiple choice menu you select which word you think is appropriate.
And again, you get immediate feedback in the form of tick Marks and crosses.
For correct and incorrect responses.
For inflection at, it looks very much the same, but instead of getting different.
For capillary items you get the same item but in different forms and you have to select which one of these is the correct one.

Now what this is a bit more of a dignified concept where you get a definition in Swedish and you can select us help translation in one of many languages, and then you have these Golden eggs and each extends for one letter.
And then you click on the buttons below with the letters to try and find the correct word.
Finally, the listener right exercise uses TTS technology to playback word to you, and then you just write what you think you have heard.
And here again, you see feedback in the form of a green happy Smiley and red and happy smiling.

And here you also have the possibility to show sentences in case you are not sure which word you heard and then you get a list of sentences containing the word in question, but it has been kept out of the sentence.
So you see the context in which the word occurs.
So going over to research info.
Doctor.
Letter is used for the collection of learner data through interaction with the platform.

So when you are doing exercises on the platform, we collect data at the moment it's anonymous collection, but in the future we would like to give the possibility of logging in and logging more specific data.
Let go has also been used for the annotation of textbooks and I will show you how that looks a bit later.
And it's also used for the experimentation and visualization of ongoing research.
So here are a few of the functionalities that we have currently.
The first one is he takes, which is a corpus example selection algorithm, which my colleague will plan has been working on very extensively.
And the goal is to find suitable sentences for language learners from corpora.
Because, as you might know, if you just select any random sentence from the corpus, it might not be the best sentence for learning.
It might contain anaphora and other things which are context dependent, so it might also be of too high difficulty level for certain learner target population.
And I don't know whether you can actually see on this slide, but.

If you just go to the He takes page, what you get is just the input fields where you put a lemma or work form and you can select part of speech but you don't have to and then you can just use the default parameters.
But here I have shown you that you can also customize the parameters and there are a lot of parameters that you can customize.

And what you get in the end are two sets of results, one set of the results is the what you actually want, and the second one is results that do not conform with all the parameters that you have chosen.
And if you click on a sentence, you can get more detailed information about why this is not compliant with what you have chosen.
For example, here in this query box you see that it contains proper names participle's an sensitive vocabulary.
So we also have text complexity prediction.
Which assesses text according to the Common European Framework of reference levels.
And this is what it looks like.
So you paste in a text and then you select whether it's a learner, essay or you want text readability, which is if you have a text which you want to give to a certain learner group.
To see what it is actually.
Good for them.
Whether they can understand it.
And the colors marked in the words of different suffer levels.
So for example, all the words marked in blue are of the A1 levels are beginner level.
You also get an evaluation which tells you the suggested overall level of the whole text, and you also get the more detailed evaluation with number of sentences and so on.
Then we have lexical complexity prediction, which is what I have been working on recently.
The goal is to predict and predict the lexical complexity of single words.
Because we have a lot of work based exercises at the moment and if you have learners of different proficiency levels, you want to give them exercises which they can deal with.
If you give them exercise items which are too hard, they will get frustrated if you give them exercise items which are too easy, they will get bored.
So you have to find out which words actually they can deal with.
And yeah, this is what it looks like here.
I have chosen 3 words, namely hunt, Volver and Baraka which are terms for dogs.
The first one hunt is the neutral term.
Vulva is a childish, endearing term for dog.
And Baraka is a derogatory term for dog and you can see that it's predicted as a 182 N P2.
For receptive knowledge.
Finally, we have the annotation editor which is used for XML markup of textbooks so that all the textbooks which are annotated are in the same format.

And it helps you by providing this interface where you can click first on crossbow can turn on lessons and it inserts the correct tags and also keeps track of the lessons in which you have created so it automatically increases the Countess of Lessons and tasks inside lessons and so on.
And you can also save your progress and continue at a later date.
So for ongoing and future work.
We are currently working on implementing a diagnostic placement test, so if you don't know what level you are you can take this test and this will give you a rough estimation of your extra level.
Then we also want to implement new exercise formats besides those that I have shown.
And also provide login function and logging of more specific user data so that we can actually track L1 specific errors.
So that we can track learner development overtime.
And so that we can adapt exercises dynamically.
So if you are using the platform and your level changes, then the system will know about that and also adapt the exercises accordingly.
In conclusion
As you probably cannot wait on this slide, letgo started out as a tool for learning and teaching by reusing a lot of existing switch learning resources.
But then it also got input from other projects such as the Swedish language Learner Learner language projects as well.

And then it also got developed into an infrastructure for research in second language acquisition and learner corpus research and in future it will get even more input from the mentioned small project.
But also another project.
This is called L2 profiles.
Reference reference
Thank you for your attention.
